Your Excellency:- I have the honour to inform Your Excellency that my Government, having cancelled the letters patent in favour of Don Daniel E, Pereira as Consul General at Hongkong, have appointed Don Buenaventura G. Seoane as Consul General of the Republic at that port with Jurisdiction in all the British possessions in Asia. Senor Seoane is a Peruvian subject and will carry on his duties as a paid Consul. I have the honour to transmit herewith, the Letters Pat vent and to request that Your Excel lency will be so good as to obtain from His Britannic Majesty the usual Exequatur in order that the said Senor Seoane may enter upon hie duties. (signed)V Political, No. 82. India Office, London, 1st September 1905. To His Excellency the Right Honourable the Governor General of India in Council. My Lord, I have Commissions issued by Foreign Governments to their Consular Representatives in India. duly received and considered in Council Your Ex cellency’s Letter No. 130 (Foreign, General), of the 13th July last, relative to the Commissions issued by Foreign Governments to their Consular representatives in India. You recommend that, in all cases in which these Commissions define the Consular jurisdiction as extending beyond the particular ports to which the Consular officers are appointed, it should be suggested to the Embassy concerned that the Commission should be limited to that particular port. 2. As regards the correspondence with the Foreign Office mentioned in the last paragraph of your letter, it should be observed that Mr. Campbell’s letter of 12th April 1905, to which you specially refer, made no proposal for suggesting to the Austro-Hungarian Government that the Commissions which they issued to their Consuls should be revised, but stated that it was proposed, in issuing the King’s Exequatur to Herr Wein, as Consul at Bombay, “ to omit all reference to his district in that instrument,” and to inform the Charge d’Affaires that “ it is the “ invariable rule not to grant the Foreign Consuls in India any “ jurisdiction outside the actual port of residence.” It is true that a suggestion for limiting the Commissions issued by the German Govern ment to their Consuls in India was made in Lord Lansdowne’s letter to Count Metternich of the 4th February 1901, but the object of that letter was to explain that no change in the position of the Consul at Bombay was created by the fact that it had been found necessary to issue the Exequatur to Mr. Hopman as Consul at Bombay only, whereas the Exequatur issued to his predecessor had had a more extended scope. And Mr. Campbell’s letter of the 4th February 1904, forwarding for my information Lord Lansdowne's letter to Count Metternich, stated “ that “ it is, of course, not within the power of the Secretary of State to “ correct Commissions issued by Heads of Foreign States, but that this “ Department has been, and will continue to be, careful in all cases, “ pursuant to the arrangement come to with the India Office, to consult “ your Department as to the exact wording to be used in issuing the “ King’s Exequatur.” 16*314. I. 1562.3. In these circumstances, it is, in my opinion, unnecessary and undesirable to modify the procedure recognised in the letters from the Foreign Office of the 4th February 1904 and 12th February 1905, quoted above, and in the letter to the Foreign Office of the 10th May 1905, which embodies the further principle that Consuls in India can have no dealings with Native States otherwise than through the British authorities. 4. The procedure in question makes it sufficiently clear that His Majesty’s Government can only recognise the exercise of consular functions at the place named in the Exequatur, which entails, as a consequence, that the Consul must, in ordinary circumstances, reside and transact business there. As regards the many foreign subjects scattered throughout India outside the limits of the ports to which Consuls are appointed, I see no objection, subject to the reservation mentioned above concerning Native States, to Foreign Governments, in the commissions which they issue to their Consuls, dividing British India into such spheres for the purposes of Consular intervention on behalf of their subjects as they may consider convenient. I have the honour to be, My Lord, Your Lordship’s most obedient humble Servant, (Signed) St. John Broheicx. I TEA! 19ft

mods.abstract: Part 5 contains correspondence between the Foreign Office and the India Office, on the appointment of a Peruvian Consul-General at Hong Kong, with jurisdiction 'in all the British possessions in Asia'.
